abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sindh On-farm Water
            Management Project for Pakistan were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. The key lessons learned are as
            follows:   Project design in an emergency situation needs to
            consider the balance of responding to urgent versus long
            term needs. The implementation agencies' institutional
            capacity and readiness should not be underestimated or
            considered less important in emergency situations. In
            countries where cholera outbreaks follow seasonal cycles,
            training of health care workers prior to the epidemic may
            help to increase awareness. Coordination of service delivery
            at decentralized level and better communication of the
            Project activities ensure community participation and
            ownership of interventions. Projects with weak counterpart
            administrative capacity require innovative approaches to
            supervision and strong stakeholder commitment.

18721911.trustfund:
TF099663-Haiti HRBF K&L Grant,TF098259-Haiti - Cholera: WB response

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Cholera Emergency Response Project
            : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Cholera Emergency
            Response Project for Haiti is to improve the health and
            hygiene practices in order to reduce the spread of cholera
            and strengthen the institutional capacity to respond to
            outbreaks. The closing date of the project will be extended
            from June 30, 2013 to December 31, 2013. The extension will
            allow the Government to finalize the remaining
            rehabilitation work, which already started in May 2013,
            taking into account possible delays due to the upcoming
            rainy season. Specifically, it will allow the completion of:
            1) rehabilitation of rooms for infectious and diarrheal
            diseases; 2) installation of incinerators for proper waste
            management; and 3) additional support for epidemiological
            surveillance. This will be the first and only extension for
            the project.

13821823.trustfund:
TF098259-Haiti - Cholera: WB response
            (GFDRR: Track III TA),TF099663-Haiti HRBF K&L Grant

repnme.cdata!:
Haiti - Cholera Emergency Response Project
            : environmental and social management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Cholera Emergency
            Project of Haiti is to improve the health and hygiene
            practices in order to reduce the spread of cholera and
            strengthen the institutional capacity to respond to
            outbreaks. The project will support activities in all
            departments of Haiti, where the cholera epidemic is rampant.
            Population growth, the unregulated agricultural activities
            and commercial utilization of resources for energy and waste
            production, significantly affect natural ecosystems and
            Haitians have a significant impact on their management.
            Nevertheless, the disadvantaged rural and urban centers bear
            the brunt of environmental degradation with consequent
            increased exposure to epidemics such as cholera. Urban areas
            are particularly vulnerable in the absence of policies and
            best practices in waste management. This ESMF provides
            information on expected impacts of the project, safeguard
            policies triggered by the project and a protocol of best
            practice management of medical care, waste and protection of
            medical personnel confronting the epidemic of cholera. These
            activities will not produce any large scale, significant
            and/or irreversible impacts. The Project is thus using a
            tried and tested approach in an emergency context in which
            the potential incremental scale of environmental impacts is
            minor and can be easily localized, and measures to mitigate
            the impacts are already standard practice among the
            non-public sector service providers. Based on the experience
            from other emergency interventions to stem an epidemic, the
            likely key environmental risks associated with activities
            for this type of project include: healthcare waste
            management, worker health and safety, and minor works.
            Moreover, it is recommended that the project does not focus
            on the financing of activities whose environmental and
            social aspects are very difficult to manage, given the
            limited available capacity of national and local
            stakeholders on issues of environmental and social management.
